original_data.question:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of difficulty sleeping and fatigue. Menses occur at irregular 35- to 50-day intervals and last 3–7 days. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. She has had an unintentional 10-kg (22-lb) weight gain over this period. She also reports decreased sexual desire and increased hair growth on her face and arms. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, increased pigmented hair over the chin and upper lip, and purple stretch marks on the abdomen. She has a prominent hump of fat over the base of the dorsum of her neck and decreased proximal muscle tone and strength. Serum studies show:
Na+ 154 mEq/L
K+ 2.8 mEq/L
Cl- 103 mEq/L
HCO3- 30 mEq/L
Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL
Glucose 236 mg/dL
ACTH 2 pg/mL (N = 7–50)
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?"

model_response:
This patient has Cushing syndrome secondary to an adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)-secreting pituitary tumor. The diagnosis is established by demonstrating increased 24-hour urinary free cortisol levels, lack of normal suppression by dexamethasone, and presence of an inappropriately elevated ACTH level. The most appropriate treatment is transsphenoidal hypophysectomy, which is 90% successful in curing Cushing syndrome. Adrenalectomy would be indicated only if the pituitary tumor was not visualized by MRI or if the patient had a primary adrenal tumor. Polychemotherapy and radiation therapy are used to treat patients with small cell lung cancer, which can cause ectopic ACTH secretion. Partial nephrectomy is used to treat renal cell carcinoma, which can also cause ectopic ACTH secretion.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Record and study of past events.

An abnormality of sleep including such phenomena as 1) insomnia/hypersomnia, 2) non-restorative sleep, 3) sleep schedule disorder, 4) excessive daytime somnolence, 5) sleep apnea, and 6) restlessness. [HPO:curators]
The state of weariness following a period of exertion, mental or physical, characterized by a decreased capacity for work and reduced efficiency to respond to stimuli.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
Lacking perfect symmetry or evenness.
A time period, or other type of interval, during which something may be achieved, obtained or observed.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
Increase in BODY WEIGHT over existing weight.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
A subjective response indicating that something is or has decreased.

The psychic drive or energy associated with sexual instinct in the broad sense (pleasure and love-object seeking). It may also connote the psychic energy associated with instincts in general that motivate behavior.
The anterior portion of the head that includes the skin, muscles, and structures of the forehead, eyes, nose, mouth, cheeks, and jaw.
The superior part of the upper extremity between the SHOULDER and the ELBOW.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and disease events of blood relatives. A patient's family medical history may be important in diagnosing existing conditions.
A state of ill health, bodily malfunction, or discomfort.
Characterized by a lack of vitality or energy.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.

A condition of having excess fat in the abdomen. Abdominal obesity is typically defined as waist circumferences of 40 inches or more in men and 35 inches or more in women. Abdominal obesity raises the risk of developing disorders, such as DIABETES; HYPERTENSION; and METABOLIC SYNDROME.

A filament-like structure consisting of a shaft which projects to the surface of the SKIN from a root which is softer than the shaft and lodges in the cavity of a HAIR FOLLICLE. It is found on most surfaces of the body.

The anatomical frontal portion of the mandible, also known as the mentum, that contains the line of fusion of the two separate halves of the mandible (symphysis menti). This line of fusion divides inferiorly to enclose a triangular area called the mental protuberance. On each side, inferior to the second premolar tooth, is the mental foramen for the passage of blood vessels and a nerve.
Lip, each instance of which is the fleshy margin of the mouth that bounds superiorly some oral orifice.
A physical exercise in which a specific muscle or tendon is deliberately flexed or stretched in order to improve the muscle's elasticity.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.

Specialized connective tissue composed of fat cells (ADIPOCYTES). It is the site of stored FATS, usually in the form of TRIGLYCERIDES. In mammals, there are two types of adipose tissue, the WHITE FAT and the BROWN FAT. Their relative distributions vary in different species with most adipose tissue being white.

A substance that dissociates to give hydroxide ions in aqueous solutions; a substance capable of donating a pair of electrons (to an acid) for the formation of a coordinate covalent bond; a substance whose molecule or ion can combine with a proton (hydrogen ion); a substance that combines with acids to form salts.
The rear surface of an upright primate from the shoulders to the hip, or the dorsal surface of tetrapods.
The part of a human or animal body connecting the HEAD to the rest of the body.
A subjective response indicating that something is or has decreased.
Situated nearest to a point of attachment or origin.
Degree of intensity or force in regard to a physical activity.
The study of serum, especially of antigen-antibody reactions in vitro.
chief cation of the extracellular body fluids.

Used with diseases for therapeutic interventions except drug therapy, diet therapy, radiotherapy, and surgery, for which specific subheadings exist. The concept is also used for articles and books dealing with multiple therapies.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
